ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Kevin Mclean
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was lovely! Very easy to reach and work with.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin is awesome. Very throughout and dedicated to running the sections. At times he was forced to over-participate when class members were quite in discussion.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was awesome. He went above and beyond and was very knowledgeable.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Very helpful and considerate.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  he was great!
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin Donihue
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Awesome power!
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was my discussion leader.

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  (the prompt asks me to identify, not give an opinion of, the TA; but Colin was a great resource for students in his section, very prompt to respond to queries and requests for help, generous with his time and counsel, patient, and fair.)
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin was a great section TA.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin McLean
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  He is very helpful
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Excellent TF, very organized and well knowledgeable.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  He is helpful to some extent, but some of his suggestion and comments are contradictory to that of the lecturer.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Was helpful and patient in explaining concepts to me

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a great class. Obviously, it is a requirement for M.ESc. students but it is also a very important and relevant course.

Loved this class, a lot more than I was expecting. As it is required I was concerned that it may be dry. But it was very interactive and pushed me to think about the bigger issues associated with being a scientist.

Excellent coarse. There is a nice balance of lecture material and proposal writing. The lecture material was well chosen, and presented in a good order. The librarian WOS lecture was less useful, but was already familiar with the resources.
Thanks to Os for his careful and thoughtful presentation of the material. Clearly a lot of thought and time went into this class. Very well structured, and clear even for students new to this field.

Kevin was pretty good. I think he could have given better feedback on my final paper outline. I feel like I followed his advice, and got a pretty bad grade on the final paper. I would have appreciated more hardline guidance.
n/a
The readings were long and numerous. They were useful and the teacher always referred to them in lecture. But I spent most of my time working on my proposal.

This course was a great introduction to the practicalities of producing science at the master's level. There are some things that were addressed in a cursory fashion, and I have some critiques about class format, but overall, it was a fanastic experience. I had a place to refine my ideas and get feedback, to think critically about the questions I want to ask, present my ideas, etc. The readings were really only so so and did not contribute significantly to my understanding, although I liked the main text and the flirting with the philosophy of science. I wish that it was actually presented slighly more rigorously, in addition to our own workshopping of ideas.
My general dissatisfaction with the course is due to the course organization and not due to the instructors.
It enabled me develop my research proposal ahead of time

Q1: Readings were long and conversational; I didn't find them helpful in terms of content, and had plenty of reading of denser articles relevant to my proposal to more than occupy my time.Q2: I gave a 4 because the assigned readings were not helpful; however, the lit review, outline, etc. assignments WERE very helpful, especially the feedback.Q10: Os could have been more organized, especially toward the end of the semester when the content lacked organization and powerpoint lectures seemed slapped together at the last minute. He wasn't present for as many sessions as I expected from him.Q12: I know Os is a terrific scientist and can be a good, patient teacher, but he needs to be more involved in the breakout (lab) sections of the course meetings, and dedicate more planning to course content, balancing that with the students' ability (and time) to delve deep into literature related to their proposals.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Developing our research projects and producing our proposals
I liked the discussion sections and the spread of the assignments. The topics discussed were very relevant to my grad school career and my future.
The dual lecture-break out group structure was great. I didn't feel that the TAs were teaching the course, but they were helpful in breaking down the material and encouraging discussion.
Proposal writing.I also like the revised schedule. The later proposal deadline allowed me to incorporate more information into my proposal, and gave me more confidence submitting it.
The assignments really pushed me to develop my research ideas and I felt more confident in my research project by the end of the semester
writing the proposal
Defining research question, doing literature review and writing proposal.
It teaches you to write proposal for academic research

Os's philisophy of science is interesting. He is honest and frank, which I like. I do not agree totally with his views though. Would be interesting to have another teacher lecture sometimes, just to get another perspective.
material was applicable to research and well-planned out, proposal writing useful, instructor/ta's were great
Writing the proposal.
The chance to really develop and workshop our research plans.The basics of philosophy of science and hypothesis testing, etc.Os is passionate and inspiring.

Lectures on the role of scientists and "the honest broker," the library system and citation software. The assignment schedule was about right and kept us at a steady pace. Presentations and discussion of the final proposals were my favorite parts of the course.
The grant panel group evaluation

Feedback on lit review, outline, and proposal. Also, practice on pitching our research proposal ideas to classmates, presenting, etc. Lastly, Colin guided his section's discussions well, keeping students on topic and providing very key prompts.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More synthesizing of reading material in class
None
None that I can tell.
The library lecture was the least useful for me. The guest was all over the place.
Guest speakers
Focused mostly on proposal writing for your own project. A bit more is required on Research Methodology itself.

I wish we would have had to turn in a draft of the paper sooner, get feedback from classmates, and get a chance to edit. THis would have given us more time to improve aand have the class be more of a process.
Application and involvement of instructor
n/a

The readings were ocassionally bland or not helpful.The format of peer review was frustraing. I felt that no one really read my work deeply enough to respond with helpful feedback, both in the presentation level, where comments were shallow, and in the mock NSF critique, where peer comments were unecessarily scathing while remaining uninformed. This was frustrating, and I hope in the future, small group workshops of the actual content of our ideas and writing can be developed in a way that we get constructive feedback in an ongoinng way.
The course needs to fit more interests. All to most of the examples given in class were in ecology.
The lecturer should arrange regular office hours. Moreover, he should avoid present theories from an ecology point of view.
Proposal format should be that applicable to non-US citizens as well, not only NFS format.
Professor involvement, lectures. Also, having a proposal due-date in time to meet NSF application deadlines would be an improvement.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective
Very cohesive relationship between class discussions and section discussions.
Definitely effective. It was great to hear Os' perspective on Tuesday and then break down the topics on Thursday.
The two generally worked well together. Some miscommunications associated with changing schedules could be smoothed over, but nothing really drastic.
Very good, TA was very organized and the discussion section was very helpful for learning and completing assignments

sometimes felt a little disconnected, and that os seemed to lectur eon what he wanted, and there was not discussion until we met as a small group. there could have been more reflection and discussion on os's lectures...
used discussion to review material in small group setting

I did not find the lab section as useful as the course lectures. I felt like the discussion section was more like a group therapy session where we tried to encourage our fellow classmates to have confidence in themselves and their research ideas. The course lectures on the other hand were full of substance.
I loved colin but didn't find the disucssions of the readings very helpful at all.More pointed and content driven discussions would have been great.
Yes, the smaller discussions were valuable.
Highly related.
Yes, however assignments that would be graded should be effectively communicated to students for adequate preparation.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Strengths: easy to get a hold of, helped explain assignments more clearly, had a great perspective as a recent MS student himself, very easy to get along with.Weaknesses: none that I can think of.
He is perfect
he was great!

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  See comments above. Colin responds well to questions, and is very willing to meet outside of class to discuss the coarse content. He is a constant source of good advice and support. Colin could improve by cracking down on late-comers, as awkward as that is.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin gets an A+ as a teaching fellow!

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was a good teaching assistant. He was willing to help, when requested, and did his best to be lead discussion sections. I would liked to have seen him take a little more control and try less to hurt people's feelings.

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  So open and helpful. Perhaps too uncritical at times. His feedback was super appreciated and very useful in general, and he was super open to meeting and offereing time.
Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was very supportive and respectful. I can't think of any way he could have improved the discussion.

Instructor: Colin MacKenzie Donihue  Colin was a focused discussion leader, showed skill in pulling out key concepts from readings and ensuring that students learned them, was organized, prompt, helpful, and fair. See Q5.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin was very responsive to our class and facilitated great discussion of the material
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Great TA. Very willing to help and very organized. Gave us good pointers and helped keep us on track.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin was great, very supportive and helpful
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Very helpful, fair, and available. Kevin did a great job leading section and giving us useful advice.

Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Kevin told me he would email scan me Os's feedback on my final paper when I was in El Salvador, which he did not do, and I did not have access to my professors feedback before I turned in the final paper. This was a little frustrating!
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  He was approachable and organized and asked good questions.

Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Strengths: he is very responsible for the discussion session and very patient to anwer questions.Weakness: It seems that he should have more communication with the lecturer about the grading and comments.
Instructor: Kevin Anthony McLean  Good in coordinating discussions and ability to interpret assignments to my level patient with non-native English speakers

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Brilliant, requirement for MESc
Requirement but also a very helpful course in terms of preparing me for my research and my future in science.

Required. I was wavering between this and the Qualitative Methods class at the beginning of the semester and am VERY glad I chose this course. Was exactly the sort of guidance I was looking for as a budding scientist.
Requirement.
As an MESc student, I am required to take this course and it really helped me formulate my research ideas.
most important class for research
As a researcher, fundamental principles for conducting a research are important to avoid plagiarism.
Taught me the basics of research and publication. It will be useful in my life
This pushed me to define my research as an MESc and think more like a scientist. I also feel comraderie with my other MESc natural science peers.
great foundation for MESc. research
This course is essential (and mandatory) to any research degree. The sooner the better.
It was great to have this intro the field at this point in my career at fes and beyond. I was glad to have the space and imperitive to apply for NSF and EPA grants.

The course is a requirement for MESc, intended to help us develop our proposal. However, it seems absurd that we must choose between social science research and natural science research. (Aren't we aiming to bring disciplines together?) Considering many of the students in the class are a bit of both - or those undertaking only natural science research must also understand the broader impacts of their project - a combination of the disciplines in one course would be more beneficial. A few students also seemed to be torn between the two courses at the start of the semester (including myself). The students in the social science research methods course would equally benefit from discussion on the role of scientists and some of the courses are already the same (e.g. library and citation software tutorials). While some aspects of the course (e.g. all of the presentation and proposals review) would make one course difficult, 3-4 discussion groups would make it feasible.
It forces me to produce a proposal but I am not sure whether I will use it in the future for my research.
Broaden my understanding of the practice of science with current concepts I was unfamiliar with in my background
Crucial to the research degree. Exceedingly helpful to have the proposal written as a result.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above
Required.
Required, see above.
Requirement.
MESc student
had to
To be prepared for conducting research and publishing paper.
I have to! I am an MESc natural science researcher!
prepare for research
It was required.
required.....i guess I thought there would be more on experinmental design and methodology, which I was craving, and still am. My appetite was whetted.
Requirement
Required
It is mendatory.
It is a requirement for research students
Research proposal for the science degree.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.
Exceeded my expectations.

Yes. I learned everything I hoped to from this coarse. The only gap I can think of is a good way to sell the Broader Impacts of research to NSF, but this is a very difficult task, and certainly got a good starting point.
Yes
yes
Yes

Exceeded. I thought it would be a silly grant writing class and I tried to get out of it! But I am so glad the dean forced me to take it it really helped push my research along. Os gave great advice when I had serious issues with my advisor.
yes
The skills gained, and time spent with Os Schmit, exceeded my expectations. I would recommend this course because of Os.

very practical knowledge about proposal writing, a difficult art. I wish more craft of pouring through science, workshopping questions and assumptions, crafting our individual question. Maybe less focus on the writing and more on the ideas?
There should more lectures about how to evaluate papers.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
I liked this style of group work. It was shorter term and allowed us to work smoothly together.
n.a.
It was a very short group exercise so no comment.
n/a
Advantages are someone to bounce ideas off of. Disadvantages are some people don't seem to care very much about the quality of their work. .

A few of us set up our own peer review group which in conjunction with Max Lamberts Peer Review Group, was infinitely morehelpful than the cursory feedback possible through the class excercises. Nonetheless, I found them useful to an extent, if only in the way they brought up productive frustration. Instructor feedback on the other hand, was extremely valuable.
Adv: I learn from my colleagues of different backgroundDisadv: decisions by student grant panel group was biased not to the merit of subject due to lack of understanding of subject.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: DO IT.
Take it if you have to, you will like it. If you don't need it but are considering some science in the future, take it. You won't regret it.

The mock NSF review at the end of the semester was fun and informative; it helped me think critically about proposal writing and has influenced how I approach my own writing. Even if you aren't planning on ever applying to NSF, it was valuable to go through the process of looking at the RFP and writing to meet those standards.
Work hard, start writing early, and meet with your adviser.
I highly recommend them to take the class.
You should take this course if you chose to conduct research on Natural Science.

The more you put into this course, the better your research will be. It is much more rigourous than the social science MESc course, so if you feel interdisciplinary or on the fence about which class to take, I highly recommend taking this one with Os. much more rigourous and worth it.
You're on your own
it is useful...
Start as early as possible on your proposal. Talk to Os early and often, to make sure you're on the right track.

Combine this course with the student based peer review options. It will hold you to deadlines in a useful way.Come up with multiple ideas and workshop them at many points. Meet with the TA and professor to get necessary personal feedbac.
They should take it
Take Os's word for it: manage your advisor early, get in touch with any actors involved in your study, as early as possible.
